Baby, you’re a rich man, too

It has been alleged that this line in “Baby You’re A Rich Man” is actually a homophobic slur aimed at The Beatles' manager, Brian Epstein.

As claimed by some, the lyrics are actually a dig at Epstein made by Lennon, fuelled by the fact that their manager was supposedly mishandling the band’s money. Due to this, as Epstein was both Jewish and a homosexual, it was believed that the lyrics “man” and “too” were switched to be rather offensive words.

In fact, Lennon and Epstein had actually been to Spain together in the early 1960s, and this was the subject of much deliberation as to whether Lennon, himself, was having an affair with The Beatles' manager. They had supposedly spent some ‘private’ time in Epstein’s bedroom in Spain (as pictured below).
Baby, you’re a rich man, too
During the session for recording the song Lennon changed the line to “Baby you’re a rich fag jew”, mocking the band’s manager Brian Epstein (Source: Ian McDonald’s Revolution in the Head)
One of the beautiful people?

“The beautiful people” was a name for the hippies on the West Coast in the US. A few weeks before “Baby You’re a Rich Man” was recorded, Lennon attended The 14-Hour Technicolor Dream, a festival for “beautiful people” in London headlined by the likes of Pink Floyd and The Move.
Happy to be that way
John may be referencing here a “natural” state of being… one unadulterated by beauty/wealth… and the happiness which comes with simply being happy with yourself as you are.

You keep all your money in a big brown bag inside a zoo
 What a thing to do

Brown bags and envelopes are associated with off-the-record cash stores (in other words, attempts to avoid tax). These lines mock Scrooge-like people who horde money and hide it away simply for the purpose of having it.

This is the first of many McCartney songs to incorporate Zoos. Later ones include “Zoo Gang”, a Wings single; “Alligator”, a track from his album New, and “Wild Life” from the album of the same name. It’s not surprising he’d mention zoos so much – he’s a well-known animal lover.
Baby, baby you’re a rich man, too
Allegedly Lennon was a little biting here… Naughty man that he is!

How does it feel to be one of the beautiful people?
 Now that you know who you are
 What do you want to be?
 And have you traveled very far?
 Far as the eye can see

In a profit-oriented world, individual wealth is often considered a sign of one’s beauty.

The inspiration for John’s lyrics in “Baby You’re a Rich Man” is a debated topic amongst Beatles scholars and fans. Ian McDonald, in his book Revolution In The Head, asserts that:

The ‘beautiful people’ was what the West Coast hippies called themselves.  The ‘14-Hour Technicolor Dream,’ an all-night festival at Alexandra Palace on April 29th, 1967 which Lennon attended, was the first tribal gathering of the British ‘beautiful people.’  This, and the fact that the session for ‘Baby, You’re A Rich Man’ was arranged at short notice, suggest that the song was inspired by the event.



A Newsweek article on the death of longtime Beatles' manager Brian Epstein (who died from a drug overdose seven weeks after the song was released) suggests that the “beautiful people” idea originated from George Harrison’s claim that “the song touted an uplifting, Eastern-tinged message: the idea that anyone can be "rich” because richness comes from within.“ Rolling Stone magazine, echoes a similar altruistic view, claiming that:

The title came from McCartney, but the spirit was pure Lennon. The working-class hero loved nothing better than tweaking the moneyed class: “The point was, stop moaning — you’re a rich man, and we’re all rich men, heh heh, baby!” he said. When Lennon sang, “How does it feel to be one of the beautiful people?” he was talking to himself.

Yet, the warmth suggested by these interpretations is blunted by sources claiming that John’s lyrics in “Baby You’re a Rich Man”  represent his dissatisfaction with the increasingly distressed attitude of Beatles' manager, Brian Epstein. This theory is supported by allegations that Lennon sang “baby you’re a rich fag jew” in the studio.

This song is about how everybody can have the things that matter, and it has nothing to do with material possessions. The Beatles use classic reversal – highlighting the opposite reaction (celebrating wealth) while actually pointing out that wealth comes in the form of intangible human relations.
Tuned to a natural E
A “natural” note in western music is one which is neither flat nor sharp.
Now that you’ve found another key
The metaphor of relating a musical key to a state of mind can be found in the Harrison-penned Only a Northern Song.
